superseded by https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JOHNZON-108

Hello @kumm , a few comments:

1. the map handling was intentional cause it doesn't target big numbers generally but only small ones (config). However we can enhance it a bit as you propose.
2. the convertTo new handling is however a regression in term of performance and behavior since double numbers become bigdecimal so you need to adapt. Don't forget to revert the deletion you did in the test, it is more important to support double than BigDecimal.

Overall I think the idea is good but ensure you use (in order) these types:

1. int
2. long
3. double
4. BigDecimal

cause it is the way it is casted in practise and rarely with a type check before (kind of implicit contract in term of usage I'd say).

Can you update this PR to support double please and add it back in the test?
yes, I am going to update this.

I'm not sure it's a good strategy to decide whether the JsonNumber should be a Double or BigDecimal.
It depends on use-case. 
Any feedback are welcome.

If you think about Map<String, ?> usage it is rarely for very big numbers, more for config and direct double casting is often done cause you know what kind of number you get. If you have another proposal I'm happy to discuss it (I'm not 100% happy too with this stratégy).

What about a MapperConfig setting?
Something like USE_BIG_DECIMAL_FOR_FLOATS here: https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-databind/wiki/Deserialization-Features
sounds good to me
should I implement it as a new PR (new story), on top of this, or just update this one?
there is fine, guess you will just replace some existing conditions by the new flag
missed to comment after update, but it's updated

Looks almost good for me, only missing part if the wiring of that config in the exposed object like *Provider (JAXRS providers), can you add it (just a setter returning void generally). Except that it is a great patch!

Thanks, done.
Just a question: setSerializeValueFilter intentionally left out from WildcardConfigurableJohnzonProvider?
Dont think so, pby a miss
applied, thanks a lot @kumm

It was a pleasure.
Closing it.

Hi @bcluap ,

what about just importing jsonb converters instead of creating another "branch" and 2 parallel code bases to maintain?

-> https://github.com/apache/johnzon/blob/master/johnzon-jsonb/src/main/java/org/apache/johnzon/jsonb/JohnzonBuilder.java#L439
Will create new pull request incorporating jsonb builders
Made changes and will include in new pull request
Any chance of this being included. Been using the patch for a while and it works perfectly

@derekm 

Thanks for your input. I was wondering about an approach of looping through different formats looking for the best match but my concern was the performance implications, I did a quick test now over 50M iterations of parsing an ISO 8601 date string (the most common format) with the 2 different implementations and the approach of testing each format for the best match is 10X slower. I have no doubt that my implementation is a bit hacky with all the string analysis (not proud of the code :-) ) but I coded it for raw speed due to the frequency of it being used.

Yeah, I see... Your algorithm takes a sort of branch-and-bound strategy by examining the input string for characteristics unique to a group of formats. I could probably add a similar pre-processing step that turns date patterns on & off. Thanks for the input & benchmark!

@bcluap -- Your previous performance tests demonstrate the fact that my naive approach tests on average 10 patterns before attempting any ISO 8601-related patterns.

As your latest commit demonstrates, supporting extensions or additions to the date patterns is an important feature of a utility library such as this.

What if each pattern could be defined with a set of predicates that test for whether the pattern should be included in parsing attempts?

If each pattern could provide its own set of pre-processing predicates, could the "Is 'T' the eleventh character?" test become shared somehow so it is only executed once for all patterns with that predicate? ... Even if it couldn't initially, might repeated execution of predicates be a worthwhile trade-off for extensibility vs. minimizing number of operations?

Hi Derek,

Yea I get you - some sort char streaming where a parser works through the
string one char at a time passing each to a set of patterns that are
"listeners"  and opt-out as they see that their predicates are not met.
Then by the end of the string the patterns remaining are run till one
replies without an error.

I guess its kind of like my logic but in a more modular fashion where each
pattern decides its criteria as opposed to a "big brother" logic tree that
has knowledge of all the patterns.

I'll see what I can come up with. Pretty busy at the moment getting a new
company off the ground but will find some time. What are the timelines
looking like for getting a new 7.0.5 TomEE build out with the Johnzon
changes - I'm running my own Johnzon fork right now and its getting messy
:-)

Cheers

Paul

Paul @bcluap -

I'm not affiliated with TomEE. I accident'd across this PR because I broke your TomEE server's Swagger 2.0 / OpenAPI 3.0 integration here: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-core/pull/2627

I took an interest in this PR because I've jumped down this rabbit hole with respect to Jersey's content type negotiation & date parsing routines since 2014, and my work there is yet to be accepted (in part due to my own availability in fulfilling commitments following code reviews & obvious changes) ... and now Jersey is being transferred to the Eclipse Foundation, pausing development further as I'm finally getting back into it!

If we could combine our approaches into a library that both Johnzon & Jersey could use, that might be an amazing feat of engineering! (If the pre-processor predicates that test positive select more than one pattern, you'll want my selection-of-successful-parsings algorithm from my Jersey code! And maybe some of the patterns and tests, too.)

Re: maintaining private forks, I feel your pain! I'm maintaining a private SNAPSHOT build of Jersey with improvements to its proxy client (an early predecessor to MicroProfile Rest Client 1.0 that actually had little to no influence on the MP Rest Client spec [MP Rest Client authors didn't know about `jersey-proxy-client` until late in spec writing]).

I have been working with @johnament on @hammock-project lately. I know John is a Johnzon user (fittingly), but I don't know how close to TomEE contacts he is. Perhaps I'll help by trawling twitter for a TomEE/Johnzon authority...

Cheers,

Derek

PS: Here is my previous work in Jersey on this topic:

https://github.com/jersey/jersey/issues/2814

https://github.com/jersey/jersey/pull/94

Hi folks!

Thanks a lot for your feedback! 
github pull requests are - for a good reason - not the communication of choice at ASF projects.
I personally have seen it way too many conflicts with ambugious ticket numbers, e.g. #5 which exists in dozen downstream repos with different content. And there are dozen more issues with the simple github ticket system for projects at ASF scale.

Of course we love all the discussions and I'd like to pull them over to our official issue tracker 
and mailing lists. http://johnzon.apache.org/mail-lists.html
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JOHNZON

I'll gradually work through the open PRs and pull them over. 
Happy to see you over there!

txs and LieGrue,
strub

Thanks James! PR got applied in commit 2f0cb1b54bb216280ba55b71373d
Not sure how to close it here on github though ;)

I came back to close up all the PRs and there is good news: support for time types is already available in Johnzon because it's required by the JSON-B spec even.
So I think we can consider this PR closed - txs!

Hi @amoscatelli,

1. can you fix the formatting diff please to ensure the patch is "clean"?
2. can you just hardcode a type in https://github.com/apache/johnzon/pull/18/files#diff-173d2c457f1e7c92c8500cb2d20edf0eR166 since the type is not repsected for the resolution (the provider will handle all json types but the init will only provide a single one, Object.class can be enough when you do getContext). Alternative is to not cache (delegate) the jsonb instance but it would slow down the runtime too much to be a valid default IMHO.
3. I really the like the test but is it possible to not add the provider by default to ensure other tests don't use that mecanism (to cover the else codepath)?

Otherwise it looks like a very good - and relevant - addition

Romain

OK for point 1 and point 3 : done !

I do not agree on point 2 :
Adherence to the specification should be more important. getContext expects the type/class and, to increase the reusability of this class, I think we should keep on passing the actual type/class. We don't know what kind of logic could be used by others or in future to return a Jsonb from a Provider depending on the passed type. So I would not hardcode it for the sake of flexibility. 

I'll try to rewrite the code to make both of us happy.
Give me a couple of minutes.

@amoscatelli: agree we should respect the spec but the spec doesn't define what the type is used for. Concretely it is used to get an instance of the "context" relevant for the type. In your case whatever type you have you will use the same instance. An alternative is the following one:

1. get rid of the atomicref to use a Supplier<Jsonb>
2. at first request check if the contexprovider gives an instance, if not -> set a "constant" supplier ( () -> instance ), if so just use the context provider instance ( () -> providers.get(....).getContext(type) ) without any cache

this keeps the same default and aligns on the context provider API
I agree now, I was already doing something similar. Commit incoming.
@rmannibucau here we are !
I made one final fix to keep all of the old methods inside the test class

Applied - think just before the small tweaks

Created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JOHNZON-163 and updated the jsonb instance handling to ensure we don't keep recreating it which is a perf killer.

Romain

My main concern is that we start mutating the reference list and miss that we can't reuse a pointer anymore (which is a requirement). Also if you can replace the `.matches("\\d+")` by a precompiled regex it would probably save some cycles at runtime.
@rmannibucau Updated the code as per you comments can you please take a look.
@Ravisankar-Challa looks good, only waiting for the test I mentionned last week (https://github.com/apache/johnzon/pull/23#issuecomment-408423476) and we can merge
@rmannibucau Added the test case

I am correct in saying that TomEE 7.0.5 and hence Johnzon 1.0.1 still does not support Java 8 times?

Johnzon serialised a ZonedDateTime into something like:

{"dateTime":{"date":{"dayOfWeek":"SUNDAY","month":"APRIL","year":2018,"dayOfMonth":15,"dayOfYear":105,"era":"CE","monthValue":4,"chronology":{"calendarType":"iso8601","id":"ISO"},"leapYear":false,"day":15},"dayOfWeek":"SUNDAY","hour":13,"month":"APRIL","dayOfMonth":15,"dayOfYear":105,"year":2018,"monthValue":4,"nano":0,"time":{"hour":13,"nano":0,"minute":32,"second":13},"minute":32,"second":13},"offset":{"totalSeconds":0,"rules":{"standardOffsets":[{"totalSeconds":0,"rules":{"standardOffsets":[{"totalSeconds":0,"rules":{"standardOffsets":....goes on for pages

some updates to isolate the OSGi stuff a little better
- make sure the package is not exported
- make as many types package private as possible
@rmannibucau so does that mean you want to remove all the OSGi details from the original artifacts?

The point is to not take any risk and break some env - log4j broke some just adding a module-info.java :s. If not too costly Id be for it - probably using reflection to activate all we can with a single osgi module. If too much code let's go with a classifier trick short term.

> The point is to not take any risk and break some env

of course.

> If not too costly Id be for it - probably using reflection to activate all we can with a single osgi module.

Why would we need reflection?

I guess the question is do you want to make an OSGi module that encompasses all the parts together in one jar (which would mean that maybe you could remove the osgi metadata from the original jars, but that would break all users who already use them)?

OR, a slim osgi jar that is installed along _with_ the others and simply boots the parts missing for deeper OSGi integration.

the problem with both is that they are both have pretty big drawbacks:

- the Uber OSGi jar always pulls everything no matter what which is often source of more pain.
- the single OSGi bootstrap module combines disparate parts that you may not want. You may not want both jaxrs and jsonb modules!
- the next best is to have one OSGi bootstrap module per feature... which just proliferates artifacts for no good reason.

.. I suspect the second case is where you were considering relfection!!! But that is not a good idea because it means you cannot use the OSGi resolver to assemble a reliable system (because you cannot see the reflective computation until runtime). You have behaviour which changes when different jars are installed which creates an unreliable system.

The point of modern OSGi designs is to be able to see that the system will work before even assembling the runtime simply by having the resolver tell you so. This is why having the proper metadata is so important.

the one I could live with the most is a bootstrap module per feature. a.k.a. proliferation of modules.

on the other hand maven classifiers are just really painful :( they live in the realm of "mutliple artifacts per project" which is a huge maven anti-pattern and Sonatype even recommends against it.

One last comment is that I'm trying to make Apache Johnzon the poster child for a regular java library which also has awesome, modern OSGi integration. This set of changes is only one step away from that. The upcoming bnd version (and maven-bundle-plugin) will help complete that.

Do you mean next bundle plugin does not need that code at all? Can it generate one jar per module with osgi classifier with the required part per module + its feature.xml? Would be the best of all no?

> Do you mean next bundle plugin does not need that code at all?

Oh no, that code is needed. But next bnd has new bundle annotations which permit eliminating a lot of typing metadata in the pom file, helping to calculate it during build time.

> Can it generate one jar per module with osgi classifier with the required part per module + its feature.xml? Would be the best of all no?

bnd is not about creating more artifacts per project. I also would not use classifiers. I would simply create additional projects, something like `johnzon-jaxrs-osgi` which imports packages and classes exported from `johnzon-jaxrs`. Likewise with `johnzon-jsonb` (i.e. `johnzon-jsonb-osgi`). At least this way the original jars stay like they were, but the OSGi resolver can figure out the relationship and assemble a reliable runtime.

Hmm, here are my current thoughts:

1. most of the OSGi classes are generable - so we can write a mojo or temporarly a .groovy script
2. thanks to 1 i wouldnt create a new module but just a new artifact with a osgi classifier which would create johnzon-jsonb-xxxx-osgi which is smoother as convention since automatic and therefore predictable (vs distinct module which is not)

If it can wait 2 weeks i can try to PoC 1. AFAIK it just requires some constant definition and everything else can be scanned, no?

I don't see how the code can be generated. There's specific details specific to each case. I really don't like the idea of creating classifier artifacts. It's going to produce complications as it always does. If you're going to go to all that trouble, why not just create two new projects & artifacts completely?

Because creating artifacts for deployments only concern is always a workaround and not a solution IMHO. When you start to x2 the number of modules in the sources just for registration concern there is an issue somewhere (likely why OSGi does not use spi-fly like solution here but we can't help that part @johnzon).

That said, I took some time to check several of the impl I was thinking about which can have issues adding these files and it seems they don't support java 8 so what about that proposal which tries to solve the "leaking import" point:

1. we keep your bundling proposal (no new jar, neither in sources nor at build time)
2. we put all osgi code in an .osgi.* package in src/main/java-osgi folder we add through maven in an osgi profile we activate automatically during the release (through release plugin) and not in the default build to hide all the osgi dependencies from the IDE

does it sound better?
applied, thanks

I couldn't find another way to cast/convert an arbitrary `Object` to an array without copying it.

But of course, if there is already such a method in the code base reusing it is the way to go. I had a quick look, do you mean `org.apache.johnzon.jsonb.JohnzonJsonb#toArray`? If so, it would be in the wrong package to be used by `Mapper` - any suggestions where I shall move it to?

@elexx it is not a package issue I think but a responsability issue. Mapper should only delegate to mapper generator and mapper parser now so the method belongs to MappingGeneratorImpl. If you look writeArray it better handles that logic IMHO and I don't see any blocker to enable to use that logic from the mapper. Wdyt?

You are right! Please have a look at the commit I just pushed. - Maybe I should squash them to one commit, before this PR gets merged to master?
 
Quick question, why does `toStructure` handle Primitives on it's own, instead of delegating to the Generator? Shouldn't `MappingGeneratorImpl#doWriteObject` and `#writePrimitives` take care of them?

@elexx this looks good to me now, thanks a lot. About toStructure I guess it is cause I had in mind that the generator was more linked to JsonGenerator so arrays and objects but I tend to agree it should move there as well.

@struberg want to have a look before we merge?
right now really busy with other stuff. But from the discussion and a quick look over the code it looks fine. Go on!

Well, I first took a look at what you did for serialization (DynamicMappingGenerator) but was unable to do the same for deserialization. I had to change the signature of ObjectConverter.Reader because the only places where I could find Deserializers are JohnzonBuilder and JsonbAccessMode (where they are converted into ObjectConverter.Readers which need a JsonObject and not a JsonValue).

About the serialization, I added some more tests (in MoreTests) which are still failing if you uncomment some of the annotations. I was wondering, if you have a json property of type X[] or List<X> and you specify a JsonbSerializer on that property, on what type does the serializer act? on X or on X[]/List<X> ?

Concerning the ParameterizedType, on one of my projects, I had some abstract Jsonb(De)Serializers and johnzon was complaining that they did not implement the correct interfaces (because it was only looking for the PT on the concrete class only).

I tried to clarify what Types is used for. The failing test can be found in MoreTests, just uncomment the @JsonbTypeSerializer/@JsonbTypeDeserializer annotations inthe Wrapper class. You will see that the serializers are not used while the deserializers are.
/me is fetching the PR and checking the MoreTests - we can need to rename it BTW ;)
@kalgon , hey Xavier, applied your patch with a few changes, do you care having a look please? (FYI i renamed MoreTests "SeriaizersRoundTripTest" to find it more easily ;))
Hi Romain, I took a look at your patch and I have nothing to add! Great work! Thanks a lot!

Hello @rmannibucau 
You are right. My first commit was too naive.
I wrote [a small benchmarking program](https://github.com/leadpony/jsonp-benchmark) and measured the throughput of `JsonObject.toString()` using [Java Microbenchmark Harness](https://openjdk.java.net/projects/code-tools/jmh/) after I made the fix less impacting to the performance.

The result are:
#### Johnzon 1.1.11 (current stable)
```
Benchmark                                (name)   Mode  Cnt       Score      Error  Units
JsonpBenchmark.jsonValueToString  glossary.json  thrpt   25  416666.246 ± 1022.390  ops/s
```

#### Johnzon 1.1.12-SNAPSHOT (including the commit 542765dd97f02910bb78d745632aef3fd9dd5582)
```
Benchmark                                (name)   Mode  Cnt       Score      Error  Units
JsonpBenchmark.jsonValueToString  glossary.json  thrpt   25  394121.959 ± 1196.864  ops/s
```
It is slower but not so bad now.

Please note that I deleted the code escaping some range of code points: '\^@'-'\u00a0' and '\u2000'-'\u2100'. Is this handling really required?
Thank you.

Hi @leadpony, it is required AFAIK. Did yiu try to move from String+charAt to toCharArray+[] fir the iteration? Also preallocating the stringbuilder with the incoming string length can help. Then we would need to be able to bypass the escaping when relevant but this requires a cache and interning string or caching based on a hashcode will be likely costly as well and will require eviction.
To give an idea, if perfs are not impacted more than ~5% we are good IMHO, if they are we can need a toggle to deactivate that fix. But first let's try to be a bit better before adding conf ;).

Hello @rmannibucau, 
I tried moving String + charAt() to toCharArray() + [].
The result are:
```
Benchmark                                (name)   Mode  Cnt       Score      Error  Units
JsonpBenchmark.jsonValueToString  glossary.json  thrpt   25  380042.206 ± 5879.107  ops/s
```
It is slower than the previous measurement. This is because `toCharArray()` allocates additional memory for array and the memory allocation makes the code slower.
The modified code is available at branch [fix-tostring-using-chararray](https://github.com/leadpony/johnzon/tree/fix-tostring-using-chararray)

JSON Processing API is based on [RFC 7159](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc7159.txt) and the document states:
>All Unicode characters may be placed within the
quotation marks, except for the characters that must be escaped:
quotation mark, reverse solidus, and the control characters (U+0000
through U+001F). 

Therefore, we do not need to escape the characters between U+0080-U+00a0 and U+2000-U+2100. The Reference Implementation of JSON-P also does not escape these characters.

Oki so maybe split the escape method to keep escaping where it is today and drop it from toString and we should be in the 5%, right?

Btw thanks for testing the toCharArray path, string have this particularity to be optimized a lot by the jvm so classical optimizations sometime fail. I appreciate you tested.

Hi @rmannibucau,
Optimizing code WITHOUT measurement is almost always bad. 

I do not feel like optimizing the current code further because `JsonObject.toString()` in the Reference Implementation is twice faster than that of Johnzon 1.1.11 (current release) as shown below.
```
Benchmark                                (name)   Mode  Cnt       Score       Error  Units
JsonpBenchmark.jsonValueToString  glossary.json  thrpt   25  940578.189 ± 18156.788  ops/s
```
RI is not highly optimized but fast and correct.
We need to rework completely the algorithm, if you would like to make it twice faster.
Right now, correctness is of first priority for me.

Hmm, did you check where the diff comes from, cached escaped value maybe? Recall toString was not originally intended to be fast but more a debug thing but it is now a runtime API so we must enhance it IMHO.

I will try to have a look or at least help next week if you cant, Id like it fixed for next release.

Thank you @rmannibucau 
No caching. They are using JsonWriter with StringWriter, which avoids multiple instantiation of StringBuilder even when the object to be stringified is deeply nested.
@leadpony applied this one - was particularly interested in tests ;). Will check toString now. Thanks a lot for the work!
hi @bcluap yes Johnzon-1.0.1 does not support it, but if you upgrade to TomEE-8 (JavaEE 8 level) then it will work out of the box.
Thanks a lot @mkarg!

Hi @mkarg ,

There is one thing worrying me in that case - and this is why "==" was intentinoally used: DefaultPropertyVisibilityStrategy is an internal class - not sure it should have been public - but it is not intended to be used by jsonb users. So in practise you can't be in the "equals" case IMHO.

Romain

@rmannibucau That might be true, but does Johnzon really want to write code that *has potential* to fail? ;-) Whether or not this was intentional - I *did* run into that problem yesterday because the class *is public*, and I *had* to use it to overcome another bug of Johnzon: Leaving out the explicit `@JsonbVisibility` does *not* invoke the field writer (while it detects the `@JsonbProperty`, it still only invokes the field writer when the field is `public`)! So either we need *this* PR, or we need a fix for that original bug (which I cannot deliver on short term due to missing time).

@mkarg no issue on the time point I really understand, my question was really: dont we just want to make it "private" (I know we cant do "private class" but we can hide it from user land).

cc @struberg wdyt? should we expose that class? Wdyt?

@rmannibucau I'm ok with hiding it from userland, but despite that, the "reference ==" idiom is really error prone and brings hardly no measureable performance benefit compared to the "safe and clean" solution proposed by this PR. So even if we remove "public" we should fix that. I spent a full day because of these two bugs... ;-(

Btw equals as instanceof does not work, think about subclassing for example
I'm personally keen to just hide it since its "api" is not intended to be stable

Do you need such a default impl or was the explicit def just a test?
